{
  "article_text": [
    "the problem of fermion mixing in kinetic theory is important both for electroweak scale baryogenesis , as well as for neutrinos . in the case of baryogenesis one",
    "deals with the dynamics of chiral fermions at the electroweak phase transition , with a mass matrix generated by a space - time dependent higgs condensate . for studies of baryogenesis in the minimal standard model",
    "the relevant mixing occurs between the standard model quarks  @xcite .",
    "for baryogenesis in two higgs doublet models the relevant mixing is in the higgs sector  @xcite . in supersymmetric extensions of the standard model",
    "the mixing is in the chargino and neutralino sectors @xcite .",
    "we consider the dynamics of chiral fermions interacting with a plasma according to the lagrangian , @xmath0 where @xmath1 is the fermion mass matrix and @xmath2 specifies interactions of fermions with the rest of the plasma .",
    "since we are interested in a near equilibrium dynamics of fermions at the phase transition where they acquire the mass through a higgs mechanism , we shall assume that the mass is space - time dependent .",
    "moreover , we shall assume that a ` thick wall ' approximation applies , in the sense that the typical momenta of particles are much larger than the rate of change of the background , @xmath3 .",
    "since we are mostly interested in electroweak scale baryogenesis , we shall assume that @xmath4 violates cp symmetry either through complex elements of @xmath5 , or through interactions @xmath2 ( complex yukawas , _ etc .",
    ".    due to space - time dependence of the mass matrix , cp violation , which is crucial for baryogenesis , is present already in the case of two fermion mixing .",
    "basis of our discussion as in refs .",
    "@xcite are the kadanoff - baym equations for fermionic wightman functions .",
    "they are wigner transformed such that one can eventually detect semiclassical features in the resulting transport equations . in the case of several mixing flavors , semiclassical ( quasiparticle ) dynamics",
    "does not necessarily lead to an accurate description of the kinetics . in this work",
    "we investigate the kinetics of mixing fermions in gradient approximation , but without resorting to a semiclassical approximation .    in refs .",
    "@xcite such quasiclassical behavior was found at order @xmath6 in gradient expansion .",
    "the semiclassical behavior was argued on the basis of a derivative expansion and a separation of the basic equations into constraint and transport equations .",
    "the latter turned out to be naturally consistent and allowed reduction to transport equations for the spin dependent on shell distribution functions in the position dependent mass eigenbasis .",
    "exept in the case of a near mass degeneracy , the dynamics of nondiagonal elements of the wightman function could be shown not to influence the dynamics of the physically interesting diagonal ones to order @xmath6 of the derivative expansion . in this work",
    "we relax this limitation combining the basic equations differently and we are able to discuss the nondiagonal wightman functions and their highly nontrivial constraint equations , which in general are not algebraic .",
    "the resulting formalism does not depend on a particular choice of basis , resolving thus the principal limitation of the formalism presented in refs .",
    "@xcite .",
    "a similar attempt within the same schwinger - keldysh formalism has been made in  @xcite .",
    "the principal limitation of that work is that the projection onto the diagonal densities is made before the relevant charges are allowed to propagate , making thus transport of mixing fermions unfeasible .",
    "moreover , the cp - violating currents are inserted as sources into the transport diffusion equations in a phenomenological manner , which does not come out of the schwinger - keldysh formalism .",
    "this work bypasses both of these limitations , albeit in a somewhat simplistic disguise .",
    "namely , we assume damping to be flavor blind and momentum independent , having as a consequence the following two limitations . first",
    ", we can not model different damping rates of diagonal and off - diagonal densities , which may be of crucial importance for proper tracking of flavor decoherence .",
    "second , taking a momentum independent damping may give a nave picture of transport ( diffusion ) of cp - violating currents .",
    "these limitations are of technical rather than fundamental nature however , and can be overcome by a more fundamental treatment of collisions , which is the subject of a forthcoming publication .",
    "in order to study the near equilibrium dynamics of fermions in the presence of flavor mixing , it is convenient to start with the kadanoff - baym equations for mixing fermions , which can be derived from the effective action in the schwinger - keldysh formalism  @xcite .",
    "when written in wigner space , the kadanoff - baym equations for the wightman functions @xmath7 become ( with flavor and spinor indices suppressed ) : @xmath8 where @xmath9 , @xmath10 ( @xmath11 and @xmath12 denote the time ordered ( chronological , feynman ) green function and the corresponding self - energy ) and the collision term reads @xmath13 with @xmath14 .",
    "these equations are formally exact , provided the self - energies @xmath15 , @xmath16 and @xmath17 are calculated exactly .",
    "( note that @xmath17 is also given in terms of @xmath15 through a spectral relation  @xcite ) .",
    "usually one is lead to a reasonable approximation scheme for the self - energies .",
    "the one often used is based on a truncation of self - energies at a certain loop order ( for an example of a one - loop calculation of the self - energies see ref .",
    "equations  ( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom][cpsi ] ) fully specify the dynamics of fermions , since @xmath18 can be determined from @xmath19 through a spectral relation . in some situations a more convenient system of equations may be the equation for @xmath20 ( or @xmath21 ) together with the equation for the spectral function @xmath22 , which is collisionless , @xmath23 where @xmath24 and @xmath25 denote the hermitean and antihermitean parts of the mass matrix @xmath26 , respectively .",
    "now we assume that @xmath2 is governed by a set of weak couplings , and that we are interested in nearly equilibrium dynamics of the modes whose momenta and energies are not very small ( when compared with the temperature of the system ) , such that the perturbative approach is justified . in this approach",
    "one first solves eqs .",
    "( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom][spectral - function ] ) for the thermal tree - level propagators ( usually in a gradient expansion ) , and then uses these propagators to study the near equilibrium dynamics by recasting the equations in a linear response approximation , with suitably truncated self - energies .",
    "this approach was pioneered in refs .",
    "@xcite . in this work",
    "we focus mostly on finding an approximate solution to the tree level dynamics of mixing fermions in a gradient expansion .",
    "we shall not make any assumption concerning the eigenvalues of the mass matrix , such that our approach is valid also when there are nearly degenerate mass eigenvalues , which is not the case with the approach advocated in ref .",
    "@xcite , which applies when @xmath27 , where @xmath28 are the eigenvalues of the mass matrices squared @xmath29 and @xmath30 .    for simplicity",
    "we assume planar symmetry , such that in the wall frame @xmath31 , where @xmath32 denotes the direction along which the wall propagates .",
    "this assumption is justified when the bubbles become sufficiently large  @xcite . working in this frame",
    "it is not hard to show that the tree level dirac kinetic operator @xmath33 defined by the equation  ( _ cf . _",
    "( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom ] ) ) @xmath34 commutes with the spin operator , @xmath35 = 0\\,,\\qquad   s_z = \\frac{1}{\\tilde k_0}\\big(\\gamma^0k_0 - \\gamma^1k_x-\\gamma^2k_y\\big )          \\gamma^3\\gamma^5 \\,,\\qquad \\tilde k_0 = { \\rm",
    "sign}(k_0)(k_0 ^ 2-k_x^2-k_y^2)^{1/2 } \\,,\\quad \\label{sz}\\ ] ] provided the coordinate dependences of the wightman functions are of the form @xmath36 . in the rest frame of particles",
    "@xmath37 measures spin in @xmath32-direction , such that @xmath38 .",
    "having found a conserved quantity , we can write the solution of  ( [ wigner - space : fermionic_tree ] ) in a block - diagonal form in spinor space ( diagonal in spin )  @xcite , @xmath39 \\ , , \\label{spin - diagonals}\\ ] ] where @xmath40 ) is the spin projector , @xmath41 @xmath42 , and @xmath43 , @xmath44 , @xmath45 and @xmath46 denote vector , scalar , pseudo - scalar , and pseudo - vector densities of spin @xmath47 on eight - dimensional phase space @xmath48 , respectively .    upon multiplying eq .",
    "( [ wigner - space : fermionic_tree ] ) by @xmath49 and tracing over spinor one finds  @xcite ( 2ik_0 - ) g_0^s - 2isk_z + s_z g_3^s - 2im_h g_1^s - 2i m_a g_2^s & = & 0 [ b0 ] + ( 2ik_0 - ) g_1^s - 2sk_z - is_z g_2^s - 2im_h g_0^s + 2m_a g_3^s & = & 0 [ b1 ] + ( 2ik_0 - ) g_2^s + 2sk_z - is_z",
    "g_1^s - 2m_h g_3^s - 2i m_a g_0^s & = & 0 [ b2 ] + ( 2ik_0 - ) g_3^s - 2isk_z + s_z g_0^s + 2m_h g_2^s - 2 m_a g_1^s & = & 0 , [ b3 ] where @xmath50 , and we have dropped the superscripts @xmath51 of @xmath52 @xmath53 .    this basis is useful in the one flavor case ( as well as in the mixing case with well separated mass eigenvalues ) , since at order @xmath6 in gradient expansion the vector density @xmath54 obeys an algebraic constraint equation , from which one obtains the dispersion relation with a spin dependent cp - violating shift appearing at order @xmath6 .",
    "an important implication of this result is that , at order @xmath6 , the quasiparticle picture of the plasma is preserved  @xcite .",
    "when inserted into the kinetic equation for @xmath43 , and upon integration over the positive and negative frequencies , one arrives at the boltzmann - like kinetic equation for the distribution function for particles and antiparticles , respectively , which at second order in gradients ( first order in @xmath6 ) exhibits a spin - dependent cp - violating force .    in the case of several flavors however , the basis @xmath52 leads to mixing between different @xmath52 s already at the classical ( leading order ) level .",
    "moreover , @xmath52 s do not transform in a definite manner under flavor rotations  @xcite .",
    "a more appropriate basis to describe fermion mixing is the chiral basis @xmath55 and the following densities , @xmath56 these densities do transform in a definite way under mass diagonalization ( flavor rotation ) , mm_d = umv^ , m^m_d^= vm^u^= m_d , + m mm_d^2 = u m mu^ , m^m m_d^2 = v m^m v^,where the unitary transformation matrices @xmath57 and @xmath58 are chosen such that @xmath59 are diagonal mass matrices with real eigenvalues g_l^s g_ld^s & = & u g_l^s u^ , g_r^s g_rd^s = v g_l^s v^ , + g_n^s g_nd^s & = & u g_n^s v^,^^= v g_n^s^u^.     "( [ b0][b3 ] ) we easily find @xmath60 where we introduced the following notation @xmath61 definite transformation properties of these equations are apparent .",
    "indeed , eqs .",
    "( [ gr][gn+ ] ) transform just as the densities @xmath62 and @xmath63 in eq .",
    "( [ transformations : glrn ] ) .    from the antihermitean parts of eqs .",
    "( [ gr][gl ] ) we get the corresponding constraint equations for @xmath64 and @xmath65 , while the constraint equation for @xmath66 is obtained simply by taking a hermitean conjugate of  ( [ gn+ ] ) and subtracting the result from  ( [ gn ] ) , @xmath67 note that the constraint equation for @xmath63 is simply a hermitean conjugate of  ( [ ce : gn ] ) .",
    "analogously , the kinetic equations for @xmath64 and @xmath65 are obtained from the hermitean parts of eqs .",
    "( [ gr][gl ] ) , while the kinetic equation for @xmath66 is obtained by adding a hermitean conjugate of  ( [ gn+ ] ) to  ( [ gn ] ) , @xmath68 as above , the equation for @xmath63 is a hermitean conjugate of  ( [ ke : gn ] ) .",
    "the collision terms and the self - energies of the constraint  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) and kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) can be easily reconstructed from eqs .",
    "( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom][cpsi ] ) by using the methods developed in refs .",
    "@xcite , and shall be addressed elsewhere .",
    "the kinetic and constraint equations represent an exact tree - level description of fermionic dynamics in the presence of bubble walls with planar symmetry .",
    "we will now show how to solve equations  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) and  ( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) in a gradient expansion , but without performing flavor rotations before we decouple partially the equations , in contrast to what was done in refs .",
    "to get an idea about the classical quasiparticle limit of our solutions , we first consider the constraint equations to lowest ( classical ) order , which are obtained from  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) by taking the limit @xmath69 and @xmath70 , 2(k_0 - sk_z ) g_r - mg_n - g_nm & = & 0 [ cr ] + 2(k_0 + sk_z ) g_l - m g_n- g_n m&= & 0 [ cl ] + 2k_0 g_n - is _ z g_n - m g_r - g_l m & = & 0 , [ cn ] where for notational simplicity here and in the subsequent text we drop the superscript spin index @xmath47 . in order to solve these equations to lowest order",
    ", it is convenient to make use of the self - consistency of the system of equations  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) and  ( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) ( _ cf . _",
    "@xcite ) , and use the solution of the kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gn][ke : gn+ ] ) to lowest order , and working in the stationary limit , in which @xmath71 , @xmath72 and @xmath73 , and where @xmath74 and @xmath75 derivatives vanish , @xmath76 when these equations are inserted in  ( [ cr][cl ] ) , one gets ( k_0 - sk_z - \\{m^m , } ) g_r + m^g_l m & = & 0 [ ce : gr:1 ] + ( k_0 + sk_z + \\{m m^ , } ) g_l - m g_r m^&= & 0 , [ ce : gl:1 ] where @xmath77 denotes the anticommutator .",
    "these equations can be decoupled by multiplying  ( [ ce : gl:1 ] ) by @xmath26 from the right and by @xmath78 from the left , and insering the solution into  ( [ ce : gr:1 ] ) ( and performing an analogous procedure for the other equation ) .",
    "the result is @xmath79\\big]\\big ) g_r        & = & 0   \\label{ce : gr:2 } \\\\",

    "these constraint equations are easily solved by transforming to the diagonal basis , that is by applying on the first ( second ) equation @xmath58 ( u ) from the left and @xmath82 ( @xmath83 ) from the right , we find that the mass shells of @xmath84 and @xmath85 are identical , @xmath86 where @xmath28 ( @xmath87 ) are the ( diagonal ) entries of the matrix @xmath88 .",
    "the solution is given by the spectral form , @xmath89 where @xmath90 denote distribution functions .",
    "( the indices @xmath47 and @xmath91 are here restored and @xmath92 . )",
    "it now immediately follows that the dispersion relations for the densities @xmath93 are given by @xmath94 from  ( [ spectral - sol : gr][spectral - sol : gl ] ) one infers that , while the diagonal densities @xmath95 are projected on the standard classical shells , @xmath96 , the shells of the off - diagonal densities @xmath93 ( @xmath97 ) are given by @xmath98 in  ( [ dispersion - relation : ij ] ) , and are in principle different for each choice of @xmath99 .",
    "a particularly simple case is when there are only two fermionic flavors and only one off - diagonal shell . in this case @xmath85 and @xmath84 can be decomposed into diagonal and transverse densities as follows , @xmath100 where @xmath101 the projection operators are defined as p_r^t & = & , p_r^d = 1 - p_r^t [ p_r ] + p_l^t & = & , p_l^d = 1 - p_l^t [ p_l ] where @xmath102 ^ 2 - { \\rm det}(m^\\dagger m ) = [ { \\rm tr}(m m^\\dagger)/2]^2 - { \\rm det}(m m^\\dagger)$ ] .",
    "this notation has its origin in rewriting @xmath103 in terms of the pauli algebra , @xmath104 , @xmath105 = 2i\\epsilon^{ijl}\\sigma^l$ ] , such that @xmath106 , where we have used the fact that @xmath107 is an invariant . in the frame",
    "in which @xmath30 ( @xmath108 ) is purely diagonal , @xmath109 ( @xmath110 ) are diagonal , and @xmath111 ( @xmath112 ) are off - diagonal and thus transverse , which explains the notation in  ( [ grl : d+t][grl : dt ] ) .    using the projectors @xmath113 and @xmath114 , the constraints for the diagonal and transversal parts decouple and read ( k^2 - mm^ ) g^d_l & = & 0 + ( k^2 - ( mm^)^0 - ) g^t_l & = & 0 in deriving these equations we used , @xmath115=0 $ ] , @xmath116 and @xmath117\\big ] = 4\\mathbf{m^2}g^{t}_l$ ] .",
    "similarly , we have ( k^2 - m^m ) g^d_r & = & 0 + ( k^2 - ( m^m)^0 - ) g^t_r & = & 0 since both @xmath118 and @xmath29 are hermitean , @xmath119 , and the dispersion relations for the @xmath120- and @xmath121- chiralities are identical at the leading order in gradients , @xmath122 an analysis of the constraint equations  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) shows that at higher order in gradients the diagonal and transverse shells mix in a manner which includes the derivative @xmath123 , leading to nonalgebraic constraints for the wightman functions , and thus seemingly breaking the quasiparticle picture of the plasma , which questions the validity of any on - shell description of the dynamics of cp - violating densities , which necessarily involve higher order gradients . the situation is more complex however , than this simple argument seems to indicate . as we show in the next section , in spite of this problem with the constraint equations , one can solve the tree - level kinetic equations to an arbitrary high order in gradients , thanks to the fact that , in stationary situations , the kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) do not involve @xmath124 , and thus the tree - level dynamics of the wightman functions @xmath125 , @xmath126 and @xmath127 and the corresponding on - shell densities ( obtained by @xmath124-integration ) are identical .",
    "( in nonstationary situations off - shell effects may be important however , which is indicated by the @xmath124 dependences appearing in the @xmath74 and @xmath75 derivatives in eqs .",
    "( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) . )",
    "this also means that stationary tree - level dynamics is completely specified by the on - shell solution of the corresponding dirac equation , which is by no means true in general situations .",
    "the importance of the leading order analysis of the constraint equations presented here stems from the fact that it allows for the on - shell projection of the collision term and self - energies at leading order in gradients , such that it is essential for a self - consistent derivation of the kinetic equations for mixing fermions , provided one approximates the collision term at leading order in gradients .",
    "using ( [ ke : gn : low][ke : gn+:low ] ) in ( [ ke : gr ] ) and ( [ ke : gl ] ) to lowest order , and working in the stationary limit , we get _ z g_r + & = & 0 + _ z g_l + & = & 0 .",
    "[ ke : rl : leading ] from the solutions of these equations @xmath128",
    "\\big ) g_{r}(k_z,0 ) \\,,\\qquad   \\label{gr : leading } \\\\",
    "g_{l}(k_z , z )     & \\simeq &   { \\rm exp}\\big (                   -\\frac{i}{2k_z}\\int_0^z dz^\\prime[m m^\\dagger(z^\\prime),\\cdot ]                        \\big ) g_{l}(k_z,0 ) \\label{gl : leading}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] we see that the diagonal and off - diagonal densities ( when viewed in the diagonal basis , @xmath129 , @xmath130 ) exhibit a qualitatively different behavior .",
    "the diagonal densities do not evolve , while the off - diagonals exhibit the vacuum oscillations , well known from the neutrino studies .",
    "note the identical evolution of the @xmath120 and @xmath121 chiralities , when viewed in the diagonal basis .",
    "note further that in the case of two mixing fermions , we have @xmath131 = 0 $ ] , @xmath132 = 0 $ ] , @xmath133 = 2i ( \\mathbf{m}^2\\times\\mathbf{g}_r^t)\\cdot\\vec\\sigma$ ] and @xmath134= 2i(\\mathbf{m}^2\\times\\mathbf{g}_l^t)\\cdot\\vec\\sigma$ ] , such that the transverse densities rotate with the frequency specified by @xmath135 .",
    "in stationary situations , one can rewrite the system of kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gr][ke : gn+ ] ) in terms of the chiral densities @xmath84 and and @xmath85 only , valid for all orders in gradient expansion , @xmath136 note first that the chiral densities @xmath84 and @xmath85 couple through derivative terms only , which justifies the use of the chiral densities in writing the kinetic equations for mixing fermions .",
    "next , equations  ( [ ke : gr : exact ] ) and  ( [ ke : gl : exact ] ) are transformed into each other by the following replacements , @xmath137 , @xmath138 and @xmath139 ( see _ e.g. _ eqs .",
    "( [ ce : gr:1][ce : gl:1 ] ) ) , defining thus the symmetry , which relates the dynamics of the chiral densities @xmath64 to @xmath65 .",
    "furthermore , we have arrived at eqs .",
    "( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) without using the constraint equations  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) .",
    "this procedure has the advantage that @xmath124 appears nowhere in eqs .",
    "( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) , implying that the kinetic equations for the distribution functions @xmath140 and @xmath141 , defined as the ( positive and negative ) frequency integrals of @xmath142 and @xmath143 , have exactly the same form as  ( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) , resolving thus the problem of closure of the on - shell kinetic equations .",
    "we emphasize that the ( tree - level ) closure is thus achieved , even though the constraint equations are nonalgebraic .",
    "one consequence of the nonalgebraic nature of the constraint equations is a coupling between the off - diagonal and diagonal densities , which is nevertheless implemented in a self - consistent manner into the kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) ( through the higher derivative terms ) , without ever referring to the on - shell structure of the system .",
    "if one had attempted to further decouple the equations for @xmath84 and @xmath85 , one would have found out that this could be achieved by making use of the constraint equations  ( [ ce : gr][ce : gn+ ] ) , which would reintroduce the dependences on @xmath124 and @xmath47 , which is not explicit in equations  ( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) .    upon expanding @xmath144 and @xmath145 in  ( [ eandedagger ] ) to second order in gradients , @xmath146 we can write the chiral kinetic equations  ( [ ke : gr : exact][ke : gl : exact ] ) , truncated at second order in gradients as follows , @xmath147 \\nn \\\\   & & \\hskip 0.9 cm    - \\frac{1}{4}\\big\\{(m^\\dagger m)^\\prime,\\partial_{k_z}g_r\\big\\ }   + \\frac{1}{4k_z}\\big (                       { m^\\dagger}^\\prime { m } g_r + g_r m^\\dagger { m}^\\prime                     \\big )   - \\frac{1}{4k_z}\\big (                       { m^\\dagger}^\\prime g_l { m }   +   m^\\dagger g_l { m}^\\prime                     \\big ) \\nn\\\\   & & \\hskip 0.9 cm    - \\frac{i}{16}\\big[(m^\\dagger m)^{\\prime\\prime},\\partial_{k_z}^2g_r\\big ]   + \\frac{i}{8k_z }        \\big [            { m^\\dagger}^{\\prime}{m}^\\prime,\\partial_{k_z}g_r        \\big ] \\nn \\\\   & & \\hskip 0.9 cm    + \\frac{i}{8 }       \\big (            { m^\\dagger}^{\\prime\\prime}{m}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_r}{k_z}\\big )      \\!-\\ ! \\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_r}{k_z}\\big){m^\\dagger}{m}^{\\prime\\prime }",
    "\\big )   - \\frac{i}{8 }       \\big (            { m^\\dagger}^{\\prime\\prime}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_l}{k_z}\\big){m }       \\!-\\ ! { m^\\dagger}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_l}{k_z}\\big){m}^{\\prime\\prime }",
    "\\big ) \\label{gr:2nd - order:2o } \\simeq 0 \\ , .",
    "\\qquad \\label{gr:2nd - order}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the kinetic equation for @xmath85 is obtained from  ( [ gr:2nd - order ] ) simply by exacting the replacements , @xmath148 and @xmath138 .    to get a rough idea on what are the criteria for the applicability of the gradient expansion , let us first recall the relevant criterion for the one fermion case , @xmath149 since @xmath150",
    ", this criterion was used to coin the term `` thick wall regime '' in baryogenesis studies .",
    "the proper interpretation of  ( [ grad - expansion : validity:1 ] ) is closely related to the validity of the wkb approximation in quantum mechanics , which is valid when the de broglie wavelength of the excitations is small in comparison to the region over which the background ( mass ) varies . in the case of mixing fermions",
    "however , an additional complication arises from the evolution of the off - diagonal densities . indeed , from the leading order solution  ( [ gl : leading ] ) we find , @xmath151 ( g^t_{r , l})_{ij}$ ] , such that the dynamics of the transverse densities can jeopardize the validity of the gradient expansion .",
    "indeed , the gradient expansion applies provided formally , @xmath152",
    "\\partial_z \\ll 1 $ ] ( @xmath153 ) is satisfied , such that the dependence on @xmath154 roughly cancels out .",
    "this implies an additional and qualitatively new criterion for the validity of the gradient expansion , @xmath155 .",
    "this criterion should be taken with great caution , however .",
    "being derived without any reference to decoherence of off - diagonal densities , this criterion may be in many situations too stringent .",
    "in particular , large differences in mass eigenvalues and low momenta @xmath156 imply fast oscillations of transverse densities , which are more prone to decoherence by rescatterings , and thus destruction , than slowly oscillating densities .",
    "we thus conclude that a complete analysis of applicability of the gradient expansion for mixing fermions is at the moment not available .",
    "let us now consider the diagonal part of the kinetic equation  ( [ gr:2nd - order ] ) and its left - handed counterpart , @xmath157 where @xmath158 and @xmath159 are assumed to be diagonal .",
    "since in the diagonal basis @xmath160 , and @xmath161 we see that the equations for @xmath162 and @xmath163 decouple , @xmath164 note that the leading order solution , @xmath165 solves  ( [ g3(2 ) ] ) , where @xmath166 is given in  ( [ g0d : leading order ] ) , such that up to second order in gradients there is no source for the axial density in the diagonal approximation .    on the other hand , the form of the vector equation  ( [ g0(2 ) ] ) suggests that in the static case ( [ g0(2 ) ] ) can be solved exactly .",
    "this is in fact not quite so , since the quantities in  ( [ sr - sl : identity ] ) are not a total derivative .",
    "nevertheless , an approximate solution can be found for a static wall  @xcite : g_0d 2|k_0| ( k^2 - |m_d|^2 + ( v(m^^m - m^m^)v^ ) ^d ) n_0(k_0 ) , n_0 = . [ exact solution : diagonal ] this is a good approximation when the mass matrix is approximately diagonal , or when the transverse elements of @xmath167 and @xmath168 are small .",
    "( [ g0(2 ) ] ) reproduces the result first derived in refs .",
    "@xcite , where the last term sources a cp - violating current , of crucial importance for electroweak scale baryogenesis studies . in sections",
    "[ domination by diagonal parts ] , [ local contributions to the currents in the mssm ] and  [ numerical results of transport in the mssm ] we make a quantitative comparison of the second order diagonal source in  ( [ g0(2 ) ] ) with the first order ( transverse ) sources , which we discuss in detail in the next section .",
    "let us define cp symmetry as the following transformations of the dirac spinors ( up to an irrelevant phase ) , @xmath169 one finds that the kinetic equation  ( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom ] ) transforms as  @xcite , @xmath170 where we neglected the self - energies .",
    "the wightman functions transform as , @xmath171 a comparison of eqs .",
    "( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom ] ) and  ( [ wigner - space : fermionic_eom : cp ] ) reveals that in the wall frame , in which @xmath172 , the cp transformation of the flow term is in our context equivalent to the transformations @xmath173 leaving _",
    "e.g. _ @xmath174 and @xmath175 invariant . from these rules",
    "the cp transformed equation  ( [ gr:2nd - order ] ) can be written as follows , @xmath176   \\label{grcp:2nd - order }   \\\\   & & \\hskip 0.2 cm    - \\frac{1}{4}\\big\\{(m^t m^*)^\\prime,\\partial_{k_z}g_r^{cp}\\big\\ }   + \\frac{1}{4k_z}\\big (                        { m^t}^\\prime { m^ * } g_r^{cp }                       + g_r^{cp } m^t { m^*}^\\prime                     \\big )   - \\frac{1}{4k_z}\\big (                        { m^t}^\\prime g_l^{cp } { m^ * }                      +   m^t g_l^{cp } { m^*}^\\prime                     \\big ) \\nn \\\\   & & \\hskip 0.2 cm    - \\frac{i}{16}\\big[(m^t m^*)^{\\prime\\prime},\\partial_{k_z}^2g_r\\big ]   + \\frac{i}{8k_z }        \\big [            { m^t}^{\\prime}{m^*}^\\prime,\\partial_{k_z}g_r        \\big ] \\nn \\\\   & & \\hskip 0.2 cm    + \\frac{i}{8 }        \\big (            { m^t}^{\\prime\\prime}{m^*}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_r}{k_z}\\big )          - \\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_r}{k_z}\\big){m^t}{m^*}^{\\prime\\prime }        \\big )   - \\frac{i}{8 }        \\big (            { m^t}^{\\prime\\prime}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_l}{k_z}\\big){m^ * }          - { m^t}\\partial_{k_z}\\big(\\frac{g_l}{k_z}\\big){m^*}^{\\prime\\prime }        \\big ) \\label{grcp:2nd - order:2o }   \\simeq 0 \\nn \\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] our primary goal is to identify the cp - violating sources in the system",
    ". a nave way of doing that would be to subtract eq .",
    "( [ grcp:2nd - order ] ) from eq .",
    "( [ gr:2nd - order ] ) , and identify the terms in the equation for @xmath177 which involve a cp - violating operator acting on @xmath178 , thus representing mixing of cp - odd and cp - even densities .",
    "this procedure leads to equations with indefinite transformation properties under flavor rotations , which is a consequence of the indefinite transformation properties of the newly defined densities @xmath179 and @xmath180 , making it difficult to disentangle the genuine cp - violating densities from the apparent , but possibly spurious , cp - violating densities .    in the following ,",
    "we propose a method , which allows to extract the cp violation from the kinetic equations  ( [ gr:2nd - order ] ) and  ( [ grcp:2nd - order ] ) .",
    "we see from eq .",
    "( [ s<>:cp : definition ] ) not only that cp symmetry is broken by the theory , but also that it depends on the basis in which the usual definition of cp conjugation is used .",
    "therefore it is helpful , instead of the usual cp conjugation , to introduce another operation g(k , x ) = g^t(k , x ) = g(-|k , |x ) . for the second equality",
    ", the relation ( [ s<>:cp : definition ] ) has been used .",
    "note that we do not want to undo a part of the usual cp conjugation , but just want to include an additional sign change of the imaginary elements in flavor space ( the coefficients of @xmath181 in the case of two mixing fermions ) .",
    "this operator has some nice properties , that are absent in the case of the standard cp conjugation .",
    "for example , q commutes with basis transformations , implying that if a quantity transform in a definite manner under q conjugation in the mass eigenbasis , it will transform in the same way in the flavor basis .",
    "( this can be easily checked by noting that @xmath182 . ) in addition , q conjugation agrees with the usual cp conjugation for the remaining coefficients in flavor space ( of @xmath183 and @xmath184 in the two flavor case ) ; in particular it agrees for the diagonal elements .",
    "hence , in order to generate a cp - violating effect , one has to create q - odd terms at least in the off - diagonal terms in the mass eigenbasis , such that cp violation becomes manifest in the diagonal terms of the flavor basis .    knowing this",
    ", we look for the transformation properties of the kinetic equation under the q conjugation and observe that all terms that come from an even order of the gradient expansion acquire an additional minus sign relative to the odd contributions from the gradient expansion . as a consequence , in the one flavor case one has to take second order terms into account in order to break q ( in this case q is of course equivalent to cp ) , since there are no zeroth order terms .",
    "this leads to semiclassical force induced baryogenesis .    in the multi flavor case , an expansion up to first order is sufficient as long as the zeroth order contributes ( otherwise the green function is everywhere diagonal in the mass eigenbasis and the problem reduces to the one flavor case as discussed in @xcite ) .",
    "let us recall the kinetic equation of the right handed density to first order & & k_z_z g_r + - \\{(m^m)^,_k_zg_r } + & & 0.9 cm + ( m^^ g_r + g_r m^^ ) - ( m^^g_l m + m^g_l m^ ) 0 .",
    "[ ke : r:1sr - order ]    the q - conjugate equation is & & k_z_z g^q_r - - \\{(m^m)^,_k_zg^q_r } + & & 0.9 cm + ( m^^ g^q_r + g^q_r m^^ ) - ( m^^g^q_l m + m^g^q_l m^ ) 0 .",
    "such that only the sign of the second ( zeroth order commutator ) term is affected .    to solve this equation",
    ", we will first determine the lowest order solution and then expand around it . the best way to determine it is in the mass eigenbasis , since in this basis the direction of the mass in flavor",
    "is fixed . in the flavor basis",
    "we can mimic this property by adding a term that explicitly compensates for the @xmath32-dependent basis transformation . in the case of a static wall profile , we can in addition include the diagonal part of the third term , since it belongs to the classical boltzmann - like flow , and we know how to handle it from the one flavor case .",
    "diagonal means in this context that it commutes with @xmath30 as it is indicated by our notation introduced in section [ sec : constraint ] .",
    "our lowest order solution fulfills & & k_z_z g^(0)_r + - \\{(m^m)^,_k_z g^(0)_r}^d - k_z = 0 , [ kin : left ] where the first commutator term vanishes , since there is no source for the transversal parts .",
    "now since @xmath185 , the solution of  ( [ kin : left ] ) is simply , @xmath186 here @xmath166 is the diagonal vector density in the mass - eigenbasis of the spectral form , @xmath187 and @xmath188 is a distribution function . in thermal equilibrium , which is formally obtained in the limit of large damping ( frequent collisions ) , @xmath189 reduces to the bose - einstein distribution , @xmath190 $ ] . in this case",
    "the collision term vanishes ( this is also obtained by imposing the kubo - martin - schwinger condition on the wightman functions ) .",
    "all influences of the changing background are then negligible and the green function depends only locally on the mass .",
    "the transverse part of the deviation from @xmath191 is in the next order given by & & k_z_z g^t(1)_r + + k_0 g^t(1)_r - k_z= s_r^(1 ) + & & s_r^(1 ) - k_z^t + ^t + & & - ^t -^t , [ source : complete ] where we defined @xmath192 .",
    "here we have introduced a damping rate @xmath193 ( which can be arbitrary small ) to fulfill boundary conditions at infinity ( @xmath194 for @xmath195 ) . at the same time this helps to cure the infrared divergencies in the sources . for simplicity , in this work",
    "we assume that the damping @xmath193 is flavor blind , _",
    "i.e. _ we take it to be proportional to the unity matrix in flavor space .    the ( particular ) solution of equation  ( [ source : complete ] ) in the mass eigenbasis is formally given by g_rd^t(1 ) ( z ) = _ -^+ w(z , z^ ) s_rd^(1)(z^ ) dz^ , [ greens : complete ] with the kernel w(z , z^ ) & = & ( - ( z - z^ ) ) + & & ( - _ z^^z dy ) .",
    "[ greens : all ] the exponential function is understood as the power series in nested commutators , and the source is rotated into the mass eigenbasis @xmath196 .    from this",
    "we can deduce the part of @xmath84 that breaks the q - symmetry ( @xmath197 ) g_rd^/q ( z ) = _ -^+ w_/q ( z , z^ ) s_rd^(1)(z^ ) dz^ [ greensqodd ] with w_/q(z , z^ )",
    "& = & ( - ( z - z^ ) ) + & & ( -i ) ( _ z^^z dy ) . [ q - breaking w ] the cp - violating diagonal part of @xmath84 in the flavor basis is given by @xmath198 .",
    "since our source is already first order in gradients , we solve the integral ( [ greensqodd ] ) by expanding all functions around the position @xmath32 and keep only the first taylor coefficients .",
    "this procedure is justified provided @xmath199 . for the mssm",
    "this leads to @xmath200  @xcite , with the expansion parameter of the gradient expansion @xmath201 .",
    "since the off diagonal entries are coherent superpositions of particle states , @xmath193 characterizes the inverse decoherence length . on the physical grounds we expect @xmath193 to be at least as large as the thermalization rate , which we take to be of the order the thermalization rate for the w bosons , @xmath202  @xcite . to get",
    "its detailed form and magnitude would require a quantitative analysis of the collision term for mixing fermions however , which is beyond the scope of this work .",
    "here we take @xmath193 of the order the thermalization rate and proportional to unity in flavour space .    assuming that @xmath193 induces an efficient flavor decoupling and making a leading order approximation of the sine function in eq .",
    "( [ q - breaking w ] ) , the expression contributing at leading ( first ) order in gradients acquires the following simple local form , g_r^t(1 ) & = & ( k_0- ) ^-1 s_r^(1 ) , such that the q - breaking part reads g_r^t / q = s_r^(1 ) .",
    "[ green : short ] since only transverse sources lead to q - breaking terms we rewrite the expression ( [ source : complete ] ) in the more compact form s_r^(1 ) & = & - k_z + ^t + & & - ^t - ^t , [ source : transverse ] where @xmath203 , and we made use of the leading order constraint equation , @xmath204 , with @xmath205 and @xmath206 where in equilibrium and for a static wall the occupation number reduces to the fermi - dirac distribution , @xmath207 .    here",
    "we can establish for the first time the important fact that in our treatment a static wall does not induce any cp - violating charge densities . in the local approximation  ( [ green : short ] ) the following integrals are relevant for the calculation of the cp - violating source current j_r^t / q & = & - + & & ( 4k_z^2 + + ^t ) .",
    "[ currentsource : local ] the left - handed source current @xmath208 is obtained simply by the substitutions , @xmath209 , @xmath138 and @xmath210 . the second term in eq .",
    "( [ source : transverse ] ) does not contribute to the current  ( [ currentsource : local ] ) , since the integral over the momenta vanishes for this term .      to evaluate ( [ greensqodd ] ) we could just solve the integral numerically . however",
    "this would involve some technical and physical shortcomings .",
    "first , the integrand is oscillating with a frequency @xmath211 , which makes numerical evaluation hard .",
    "second , since we have parametrized the collision terms in the kinetic equation by just one parameter , our solution does not show the expected behavior in certain regions of parameter space .",
    "_ e.g. _ we expect that collisions help to isotropize the deviation from equilibrium , while the solution to equation ( [ greensqodd ] ) has a strong @xmath156 dependence , but almost no @xmath212 dependence ( @xmath212 denotes the momentum parallel to the wall ) .",
    "another feature which may play an important role is diffusion , by which particles get transported typically to distances @xmath213 in front of the wall , where @xmath214 denotes the diffusion constant , @xmath215 the wall velocity , and @xmath193 the damping . in systems with small @xmath193 and/or large @xmath214 , such that @xmath216 is satisfied , the diffusion tail may be large , @xmath217 . since for charginos of the mssm , the diffusion constant and the wall velocity are rather small , @xmath218 , @xmath219 and the damping quite large , @xmath220  @xcite , @xmath221 is amply fulfilled , and we can estimate the diffusion ` tail ' to be @xmath222 .",
    "since diffusion is symmetric and it extends to distances of the order the wall thickness , we expect it to be captured reasonably well by our simple model of damping .    to cure the shortcomings related to the local approximation , we shall solve the kinetic equation ( [ source : complete ] ) by a fluid _ ansatz _ in the mass eigenbasis g_rdij^(1 ) & = & 2 _",
    "a=0^n t_c^-a _ aij ( k_z - v_w k_0)^a _ ij(k_0 ^ 2 - _ ij^2 ) , [ fluid : ansatz ] where @xmath98 are given by the lowest order on - shell conditions  ( [ dispersion - relation : ij ] ) , @xmath223 , and @xmath224 $ ] is the fermi - dirac distribution function .",
    "note that the fluid _",
    "( [ fluid : ansatz ] ) captures the chiral nature of the first order solution , which is , for example , expressed by the leading order constraint relation , @xmath225 .    if one now takes the first @xmath226 momenta of the kinetic equation  ( [ source : complete ] ) , defined as @xmath227(k_0/\\tilde k_0 ) ( k_z / t_c)^l$ ] @xmath228 , one gets a matrix equation of the form ( here and below we suppress the @xmath99 indices ) : a _ z + b + c= d .",
    "[ momenta : matrix ] @xmath229 , @xmath230 , @xmath231 are matrices and @xmath232 and @xmath214 vectors in the @xmath233 space ( @xmath234 ) , with a_ab & = & t_c^-a - b _",
    "k_0>0 |k_0| ( k_z - v_w k_0)^a k_z^b+1 ( k_0 ^ 2 - ^2 ) + b_ab & = & t_c^-a - b _ k_0>0 |k_0| ( k_z - v_w k_0)^a k_z^b ( k_0 ^ 2 - ^2 ) + c_ab & = & t_c^-a - b _ k_0>0 |k_0| ( k_z - v_w k_0)^a k_0 k_z^b ( k_0 ^ 2 - ^2 ) + d_a & = & - _ k_0>0 k_z^a ( k_0 ^ 2 - ^2 ) + & & ( 4k_z^2 + ^t + ^t ) .",
    "the summation in eq .",
    "( [ momenta : matrix ] ) runs over @xmath235 , while @xmath236 , @xmath237 and @xmath238 are held fixed .",
    "the eigenvalues @xmath239 of the matrix @xmath240 + \\gamma c\\big)$ ] determine the damping and oscillatory behavior of the solution .",
    "due to the form of the source , the first few momenta dominate the solution .",
    "if the source has a compact support , we can deduce that outside this compact region , @xmath232 is a superposition of damped harmonic oscillations with the frequencies @xmath241 and damping rates @xmath242 .",
    "the amplitude of these oscillations is then suppressed by @xmath243 , such that fast oscillating modes give smaller contributions to the current .",
    "for special choices of the mass matrix , or in the limit where the oscillations suppress the off - diagonal contribution , the problem can be reduced to the diagonal case and the first order contributions to the cp violation , produced by the oscillations of the off - diagonal terms , are negligibly small . when viewed in the mass eigenbasis , the problem then reduces to the diagonal case , such that the first cp - violating contributions come from the second order semiclassical force in the kinetic equation .",
    "this approach was originally pursued in  @xcite , and we summarize its main results in section  [ reduction to the diagonal limit ] .",
    "we have seen that the first order terms are for large damping suppressed as @xmath244 . in this section",
    "we pose the question how are the second order terms suppressed in this limit .",
    "since @xmath193 is large we integrate the taylor expansion of the source using the green function method and notice , that the first coefficient gives no contribution ( since it is odd in @xmath156 ) and the second term gives g^(2)d_0 = \\{m^^ m - m^m^ , _",
    "k_z g^(0)_0}^d [ g2:once more ] .",
    "the term  ( [ g2:once more ] ) is suppressed by @xmath245 as the contributions in the first order terms , but in addition by two more orders in the gradient expansion .",
    "therefore we can not infer that the second order terms dominate for large damping .",
    "rather the region in parameter space where @xmath246 is large leads to dominance of the diagonal terms .",
    "however , the second order terms can yield cp violation in the trace of the green function , while the first order terms are always traceless .",
    "therefore the second order terms could be more important for generating a baryon asymmetry , depending on which contribution is more efficiently transformed into the bau .",
    "in this section we give the explicit expressions for the cp - violating currents in the mssm in the local approximation .",
    "since in the mssm we expect the damping @xmath193 to be less than @xmath247 , we are in the regime , where transport is important , such that the main intention is to make our approach comparable with former publications , in which local sources for diffusion equations have been derived  @xcite .    the most important contribution to the bau in the mssm",
    "is determined by the mass matrix of the chargino - higgsino sector with complex @xmath248 and real @xmath249 .",
    "@xmath250 the procedure how to diagonalize @xmath26 is outlined in appendix [ app : diag ] .    using this parametrization we can evaluate the cp - violating chiral source current @xmath251  ( [ currentsource : local ] ) and @xmath252 . since this",
    "sources are traceless , the relevant quantities are @xmath253 and @xmath253 , where @xmath254 in flavour space . under the trace eq .",
    "( [ currentsource : local ] ) can be reduced to the form @xmath255                                { \\rm tr}\\big [ ( v\\sigma^3v^\\dagger)^t                        \\big\\ {                             4 k_z^2({vv^\\dagger}^\\prime)^t                           + \\big(v(m\\ddp m \\!-\\ ! m\\dd m^\\prime)v^\\dagger\\big)^t",
    "\\big\\ }                      \\big ] \\nn\\\\ & &   \\hskip 0.3 cm   + \\ ; { \\rm tr}\\big[\\delta(k^2\\!-\\!|m_d|^2)n\\big ]       { \\rm tr}\\big [ ( v\\sigma^3v^\\dagger)^t                  \\big(\\sigma^3 v(m\\dd m)^\\prime v^\\dagger\\big)^t               \\big ]      \\!\\bigg ) .",
    "\\label{currentsource : local:2}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the traces can be easily evaluated by making use of appendix  a , @xmath256        & = & 4i\\frac{1}{\\lambda^2}\\im(m_2\\mu_c )                \\big(u_1^\\prime u_2 - u_1 u_2^\\prime\\big ) \\nn\\\\ { \\rm tr}\\big [ ( v\\sigma^3v^\\dagger)^t                           \\big(v(m\\ddp m \\!-\\ !",
    "m\\dd m^\\prime)v^\\dagger\\big)^t",
    "\\big ]        & = & -4i\\frac{\\bar\\delta}{\\lambda^2}\\im(m_2\\mu_c )                   \\big(u_1 u_2\\big)^\\prime \\nn\\\\       { \\rm tr}\\big [ ( v\\sigma^3v^\\dagger)^t                  \\big(\\sigma^3 v(m\\dd m)^\\prime v^\\dagger\\big)^t               \\big ]        & = & -4i\\frac{1}{\\lambda}\\im(m_2\\mu_c )                   \\big(u_1^\\prime u_2 - u_1 u_2^\\prime\\big ) \\,,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where we used @xmath257 .",
    "the form of the chiral source can be then written as ( we reinsert the spin superscript ) @xmath258 where @xmath259 , @xmath260 , and we defined the integrals , _ ( n)1/2 & & t_c^2-n _ k_0>0 k_z^n ( k^2 - m_1/2 ^ 2 ) + _ ( n)^0 & & ( _ ( n)1 + _ ( n)2 ) , _ ( n)^3 ( _ ( n)1-_(n)2 ) , = m_1 ^ 2 - m_2 ^ 2 .",
    "[ eta : def ] the functions @xmath261 and @xmath262 are dimensionless and depend only weakly on @xmath246 in the region where @xmath263 , but generate a behavior @xmath264 in the limit @xmath265 . in our former publication",
    "@xcite we neglected off - diagonals , so we were working in the limit of large @xmath246 .",
    "several comments are now in order",
    ". equations  ( [ jsqr][jsql ] ) represent the new cp - violating sources which were calculated by solving iteratively the quantum kinetic equations for two mixing charginos of the mssm .",
    "these sources are absent in the single fermion case , in which case the diagonal semiclassical force source dominates .",
    "both of the chiral source currents are proportional to spin , and hence when summed over spin the sources vanish , @xmath266 nonvanishing sources are obtained only when a weighted sum over spin is performed ( for a related discussion of the semiclassical force source see refs .",
    "@xcite ) , @xmath267 and @xmath268 . to get the source currents for a moving wall",
    ", we assume that in the plasma frame the current transforms as a lorentz vector , which is reasonable provided diffusion is inefficient . in order to facilitate a comparison with the existing work on electroweak baryogenesis sources , it is instructive to calculate the vector and axial source currents . from eqs .",
    "( [ jsqr][jsql ] ) we then easily get for the currents in the plasma frame and for a moving wall @xmath269         \\eta_{(0)}^3 \\label{jsq0 } \\\\ { \\rm tr}\\big(\\sigma^3 j_\\mu^{\\slash{q}}\\big )     & \\equiv & { \\rm tr}\\sigma^3 \\sum_{s}\\frac{s}{2}\\big(j_{r\\mu}^{s\\slash{q } }                               - j_{l\\mu}^{s\\slash{q } }                            \\big )           = 2\\frac{\\im(m_2\\mu_c)}{t_c^2 }               \\frac{u_1 ^ 2-u_2 ^ 2}{t_c^2 }         \\big[\\partial_\\mu(u_1 u_2)\\big ] \\eta_{(0)}^3 \\nonumber\\\\    & &    \\hskip 4.62 cm       -\\ ;    2\\frac{\\im(m_2\\mu_c)}{t_c^2 }                      \\big ( u_2\\partial_\\mu u_1 - u_1\\partial_\\mu u_2\\big )                     \\big(\\eta_{(0)}^0 + 4\\eta_{(2)}^3\\big ) \\,,\\qquad \\label{jsq5}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] such that the sources in the local approximation neatly split into the plus and minus contributions , @xmath270 and @xmath271 , respectively .",
    "the axial current is sourced by the plus contribution only ( just like in the case of the second order semiclassical force ) , while the vector current is sourced by both plus and minus contributions . in the non - local case , both plus and minus terms contribute to @xmath272 and @xmath273 .",
    "these results have a similar structure to the sources found in refs .",
    "@xcite and  @xcite .",
    "the differ however , when a detailed quantitative comparison is made .    finally ,",
    "we quote the second order diagonal source calculated in the local approximation  ( [ g2:once more ] ) : @xmath274 with the definitions _ ( n)1/2 & & t_c^2-n _ k_0>0 k_z^n ( k^2 - m_1/2 ^ 2 ) , _ ( n)^3 ( _ ( n)1-_(n)2 ) . [ zeta : def ] note that , in contrast to @xmath275 , @xmath276 is not suppressed for large @xmath246 , such that the second order terms dominate in the local regime for large values of @xmath246 .",
    "in this section we will present numerical results of the fluid ansatz .",
    "the higgs _ vevs _ and the @xmath277 angle are parametrized by @xmath278 , @xmath279 and h(z ) = v(t ) 1- 1- , [ h ] + ( z ) = _ - 1 + 1- .",
    "[ beta ] if not stated differently , the parameters used in the plots are @xmath280 gev , @xmath281  gev , @xmath282 , @xmath283 gev , @xmath284 gev , and the complex phase is chosen maximally @xmath285 . the value of @xmath286 is deduced from @xcite by using the value @xmath287 gev . in figure",
    "[ fig : h+beta ] we show how the wall  ( [ h][beta ] ) looks for our choice of parameters .",
    "[ fig : h+beta ]    the wall velocity is taken to be @xmath288 and the plots are evaluated for the first six momenta .",
    "the currents @xmath289 , @xmath290 and the second order term @xmath291 are evaluated in the plasma frame , thus the expressions are linear in @xmath215 .",
    "first we will display the dependence on the number of momenta that are used in our fluid _",
    "ansatz_. fig .",
    "[ fig : n - dependence ] shows that the convergence is already very good for @xmath292 , such that it is sufficient to use only the first six momenta .",
    "-0.2 in [ fig : n - dependence ]    since the higher momenta have a slightly smaller exponential suppression factor but much smaller sources , these contributions become important in the region far away from the source , where the oscillations take place . mostly the phases of the oscillations",
    "are influenced , such that quantitative statements barely change for @xmath293 .",
    "the plots fig .",
    "[ fig : muc_205 ] to fig .",
    "[ fig : muc_450 ] show all three currents for the values @xmath294 gev and @xmath283 gev . for small @xmath246 , respectively @xmath295 , the solution is oscillating and has rather large amplitudes .",
    "these oscillations are , as expected , suppressed for larger values of @xmath246 and a local contribution remains .",
    "for @xmath296 the second order contribution , which shows a weaker dependence on @xmath246 , begins to dominate .",
    "when @xmath246 is large , the first order currents are suppressed due to efficient decoherence . in the bau ,",
    "the second order terms start to dominate earlier since , for the first order terms , the oscillations and inefficient transport prevent in part an efficient source conversion to baryon asymmetry , while the second order terms are transported more efficiently and without oscillations , such that that give a truly non - local contribution .",
    "the term resulting from the combination @xmath297 is suppressed due to the fact that @xmath298 is small .",
    "in addition , the terms that include @xmath299 are smaller than the terms including @xmath300 .",
    "-0.2 in [ fig : muc_205 ]    -0.2 in [ fig : muc_240 ]    -0.2 in [ fig : muc_300 ]    -0.2 in [ fig : muc_450 ]    the axial vector current @xmath290 , that is normally the largest contribution to the source , is suppressed for small @xmath246 due to the factor @xmath301 in eq .",
    "( [ jsq0 ] ) and in this region the vector current @xmath289 becomes the most important one .",
    "in this article we have presented a method to solve schwinger - dyson equations for cp - violating densities for mixing fermions in a space time dependent background .",
    "the transition to the chiral basis was important for the partial decoupling of the different coefficients in spinor space .",
    "the terms that can appear in the kinetic equations written in chiral basis all have the same transformation properties under flavor basis transformations . as an intermediate result",
    ", we have obtained the formally exact equations  ( [ ke : gl : exact ] ) , in which only two of the 16 coefficients in spinor space remain coupled to each other .",
    "next , we have found that the off - diagonal densities exhibit oscillations at lowest order in gradient expansion . even though they vanish without space - time dependent background",
    ", these terms ought to be treated by taking into account oscillations as soon as they are sourced .",
    "in section  [ cp - violating sources ] we advance a novel definition of cp violation in kinetic equations with mixing flavors . according to our definition ,",
    "when kinetic equations with mixing fermions are truncated at first order in gradients , only the inclusion of flavor oscillations ( formally expressed through the commutator term ) gives raise to nonvanishing cp violation in the diagonal entries of the flavor basis .",
    "the same is of course true for the chargino and neutralino sectors in supersymmetric extensions of the standard model .",
    "this is the main difference between our approach and the approach advocated in literature  @xcite . without taking the flavor oscillations into account",
    ", the cp - violating densities would stay in the off - diagonal entries even after rotation into the flavor basis .",
    "our approach to second order diagonal sources ( semiclassical force ) differs from the treatment advocated in refs .",
    "in order to arrive at a local analytic estimate in flavor basis , we have considered the limit of large damping , @xmath302 .",
    "the cp - violating axial current  ( [ j02:cp ] ) is in this case proportional to the trace in flavor space .",
    "the source from semiclassical force in  @xcite is calculated in the mass eigenbasis in the limit when @xmath303 , and it was found to be proportional to the difference of flavor axial densities , @xmath304 . moreover , in our numerical treatment we calculate the source by taking account of both flavor mixing and transport , while the same source has been treated in the literature in the diagonal approximation in the mass eigenbasis .",
    "apart from the _ plus _ contribution , @xmath305 , we also found the _ minus _ contribution , @xmath297 .",
    "the plus contribution is sourced by both the first order off - diagonals and by the second order diagonals .",
    "the minus term plays an important role in the approach advocated in refs .",
    "@xcite , especially near the degeneracy ( small @xmath246 ) , where it exhibits a resonant enhancement .",
    "when compared with our results , in the region of near degeneracy we find a weak enhancement in all contributions to the cp - violating vector current , such that the minus contribution remains subdominant .    by performing a numerical study of fluid equations , we have analysed the cp - violating vector and axial vector currents for a slowly moving wall , and found that , in the nonlocal regime , in which the currents are only weakly damped @xmath306 , the first order terms provide a dominant contribution to the cp - violating currents if @xmath307 ( @xmath28 ( @xmath308 ) denote the mass eigenvalues ) is smaller than about @xmath309 .",
    "whether this statement remains true with respect to the baryon asymmetry remains unclear , since the oscillations , poor transport and the tracelessness of the first order terms could prevent an efficient production of bau .    a more comprehensive comparison with the work of refs .",
    "@xcite and  @xcite , and the explicit calculation of the bau is postponed to a forthcoming publication .",
    "we would like to thank steffen weinstock and marco seco for numerous useful discussions .",
    "the chargino - higgsino mass matrix is given by @xmath250 the mass matrix @xmath26 is diagonalized by the biunitary transformation @xmath310 with @xmath311 and @xmath312 where we defined @xmath313 .",
    "note that @xmath314 and @xmath315 can be obtained from @xmath236 and @xmath316 by the replacements , @xmath317 , @xmath318 and @xmath319 , such that @xmath320 , as indicated in  ( [ v ] ) .",
    "the mass eigenvalues - squared are given by @xmath321 and can be calculated quite simply by noting that @xmath322 .",

    "g.  d.  moore and t.  prokopec , `` how fast can the wall move ?",
    "a study of the electroweak phase transition dynamics , '' phys .",
    "d * 52 * ( 1995 ) 7182 [ arxiv : hep - ph/9506475 ] ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we derive transport equations for fermionic systems with a space - time dependent mass matrix in flavor space allowing for complex elements leading to cp violation required for electroweak baryogenesis . </S>",
    "<S> by constructing appropriate projectors in flavor space of the relevant tree level kadanoff - baym equations , we split the constraint equations into `` diagonal '' and `` transversal '' parts in flavor space , and show that they decouple . </S>",
    "<S> while the diagonal densities exhibit standard dispersion relations at leading order in gradients , the transverse densities exhibit a novel on - shell structure . </S>",
    "<S> next , the kinetic equations are considered to second order in gradients and the cp - violating source terms are isolated . </S>",
    "<S> this requires a thorough discussion of a flavor independent definition of charge - parity symmetry operation . to make a link with baryogenesis in the supersymmetric extension of the standard model </S>",
    "<S> , we construct the green functions for the leading order kinetic operator and solve the kinetic equations for two mixing fermions ( charginos ) . </S>",
    "<S> we take account of flavor blind damping , and consider the cases of inefficient and moderate diffusion . </S>",
    "<S> the resulting densities are the cp - violating chargino currents that source baryogenesis . </S>"
  ]
}
